name: wind turbine construction, 4.5MW, onshore | wind turbine, 4.5MW, onshore | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2086/documentation

This dataset represents the construction of a wind turbine with a capacity of 4.5MW for onshore use. The term "wind turbine" inludes moving parts such as nacelle, rotor, rotor blades, transition piece as well as fixed parts such as the tower and the foundation. ;Reference technology for this wind turbine is an Enercon E-112 turbine. The tower is made of reinforced concrete, a relatively new technology. LCI data are based on (Chataignere & Le Boulch 2003), supplemented with some own assumptions and adapted to the ecoinvent background database for this study. Parts of the wind turbine are the following: ; - Rotor: Rotor blades (fibre-glass reinforced plastics), rotor hub, extender; - Nacelle (gearbox, generator, shaft and others); - Electronics; - Tower; - Foundation ;;Data are very rough since no real data were available for the tower and foundations mass balance, and since the detailed composition of the nacelle, blades and connection to the grid is derived from an Enercon E-66 1.5MW wind turbine. 

From the transformation of pasture land to industrial site, and from the reception and treatment of building materials and turbine parts.

This activity ends with the decommissioning of the wind turbine and the treatment of the resulting materials in the end of the lifetime.

This dataset includes 
 - all materials for the construction of the wind turbine and their treatment, but not the energy for their assembling
 - land transformation and use
 - energy needed for erection and dismantling of the wind turbine.

This dataset doesn't include 
 - the connection to the grid, which is modeled in a separate dataset.
 - the operation and maintenance of the fully finished wind power plant. It is assumed that all parts will hold for the lifetime of 20 years and don't have to be replaced. 
 - auxiliary materials such as packaging materials or vacuum fleece.  
 - any losses of materials (waste) during the processing of the different wind turbine parts.
 - neither the energy use for assembly of the different wind turbine parts nor their transportation from manufacture to the construction site.
category: C:Manufacturing/28:Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.e.c./281:Manufacture of general-purpose machinery/2811:Manufacture of engines and turbines, except aircraft, vehicle and cycle eng

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Technology: Enercon E-112 4.5MW wind turbine. This special type of wind turbine is not on the market any more, but the technology can still be taken as a good reference for wind turbines with a capacity of >3 MW built today.; Characteristics: ; - Capacity: 4500 kW;;- Diameter of the rotor: 113 m; - Length of the rotor blades: 52 m; - Number of rotor blades: 3; - rotor blade weight: 20000 kg;;- nacelle weight: ca.355000 kg;; - material of the tubular tower: concrete (+reinforcing steel); - tower height: 120 m; - foundation thickness: 2m; - cable for network connection (per turbine): 1000 m; - Lifetime: 20 years ;Source: Chataignere A. and Le Boulch D. (2003) Wind Turbine Systems. Final report ECLIPSE. EDF R&D, Clamart Cedex, France
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
This dataset valid for 4.5MW onshore wind turbines is based on one single type of a 4.5MW onshore wind turbine (Enercon 4.5MW wind turbine; where Enercon held a market share of ca.13% in the wind turbine market in 2001/02 (Chataignère et al. 2003)).

For the nacelle (440t) and blades (20t*3), data were extrapolated from an Enercon E-66 1.5MW wind turbine with a detailed mass balance.Data quality is therefore quite rough.

Primary source of this dataset is a report from 2003 which mainly refers to data from 1998. Uncertainty was adjusted accordingly.

flow.name: wind turbine, 4.5MW, onshore
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/28:Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.e.c./281:Manufacture of general-purpose machinery/2811:Manufacture of engines and turbines, except aircraft, vehicle and cycle eng

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Used for the tower and foundation. 

TOWER:
For very big wind turbines, tubular tower dimensions as normally used seem to create problems for transport. The underlying 4.5 MW Enercon prototype has been built with a fully concrete tower therefore. Hybrid towers (lower part in concrete, upper part in steel) are also an option. 
Tower data: 
The tower is supposed to be in concrete reinforced steel.
 - diameter at the base: 12m
 - diameter at the top: 4m
 - thickness at the base: 1m
 - thickness at the top: 0.6m
 - concrete mass: 5.9E6 kg
 - density of concrete: 2400 kg/m3

FOUNDATION
Foundations are supposed to be made of reinforced concrete.
628 m3 concrete for foundation (surface = 314 m2; depth = 2m)

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The glass fibre reinforced plastic of the rotor is disposed of as 50% glass and 50% plastic.
Today, it is not possible to recycle the turbine blades. When the turbine’s lifetime expires, the blades will
be dismantled into smaller pieces, which are deposited at controlled waste deposits.[Elsam. 2004b. Life Cycle Assessment of turbines PSO 1999. Elsam Engineering A/S, Fredericia, Denmark]

Literature value and estimation.

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Used for the three blades. The shares of "polyvinylchloride, emulsion polymersied" and "polyvinylchloride, suspension polymerised" in the cancelled ecoinvent v2 "aluminium production mix" dataset amounted to 12.8% (emulsion) and 87.2% (suspension) respectively. These shares have been overtaken to distribute the original amount of 4569 kg polyvinylchloride.These shares correspond to the European distribution of the different PVC types.

Sum of PVC-foam (3*279 kg) and PVC (3*131 kg) extrapolated with a weight factor from a 1.5MW wind turbine.

Additional to energy requirements for material processing, a factor of 0.5 kWh/kg material (except of concrete) after (Burger & Bauer 2004) is included with medium voltage electricity for assembly of the parts, further installation of the plant, and removal of the turbine. The value is only a rough estimation based on the potential energy necessary for lifting the relevant weights.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The glass fibre reinforced plastic of the rotor is disposed of as 50% glass and 50% plastic.
Today, it is not possible to recycle the turbine blades. When the turbine’s lifetime expires, the blades will
be dismantled into smaller pieces, which are deposited at controlled waste deposits.[Elsam. 2004b. Life Cycle Assessment of turbines PSO 1999. Elsam Engineering A/S, Fredericia, Denmark]

exchanges.description:
Literature value/calculated value. Used in the nacelle and the three blades. The shares of cast alloy and wrought alloy aluminium in the cancelled ecoinvent v2 "aluminium production mix" dataset amounted to 32% (cast alloy) and 68% (wrought alloy) respectively. These shares have been overtaken to distribute the original amount of 973 kg aluminium. 

Sum of aluminium in nacelle (127 kg) and in the three blades (3*33 kg) extrapolated with accordant weight factors from a 1.5MW wind turbine.

exchanges.description: Literature value/estimation. Generally a combination of tarred roads and dirt roads need to be built to provide access to the power plant turbines, which are often located in remote locations. It has been estimated that 10 km of tarred road is needed for a power plant with 25 wind turbines.

exchanges.description:
Literature value. Used for the rotor blades and the nacelle. Steel and aluminium blades are used for small wind turbines. For large ones, they have problems of weight or metal fatigue. Most modern rotor blades on large wind turbines are made of glass fiber reinforced polyester or epoxy. Carbon fiber or Kevlar seems to be too expensive for large turbines. 

Sum of different components, extrapolated with accordant weight factors from a 1.5MW wind turbine.
nacelle:
fibre glass (924 kg) and unsaturated polyester resin (2159 kg)

one blade:
fibre glass (2188 kg), hardener (525kg), polyamide (76kg)
